title: 107_hr3882
content: The Act titled "Preserving Patient Access to Physicians Act of 2002" aims to reform the Medicare physician payment update system by eliminating the Sustainable Growth Rate (SGR) payment update system. The "Preserving Patient Access to Physicians Act of 2002" reforms the Medicare physician payment update system by updating the single conversion factor annually based on input price index changes. The "Preserving Patient Access to Physicians Act of 2002" reforms the Medicare physician payment update system by establishing an input price index for physicians' services based on weighted-average input prices. The "Preserving Patient Access to Physicians Act of 2002" establishes an input price index for physicians' services, excluding changes in costs from other factors like productivity. The Secretary estimates the annual change in the index and publishes a productivity adjustment factor before each year. The productivity adjustment factor reflects the Secretary's estimate of growth in multifactor productivity in the national economy, based on data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Amendments to Section 1848 of the Act include adjustments for different years based on established updates. The productivity adjustment factor is based on the Secretary's estimate of national economic growth. Amendments to Section 1848 of the Act include updates for different years, with specific conversion factors published in the Federal Register annually. The updates to Section 1848 of the Act include adjustments for different years based on national economic growth estimates. The updates determine allowed expenditures and updates for succeeding years. In subsection (d)(4), adjustments are made for years 2001 and 2002 regarding allowed expenditures and updates. In subsection (f), adjustments are made for years 2001 and 2002 regarding various provisions such as November 1 deadlines and percentage changes. The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission will submit a report to Congress on the impact of refinements to physician payments after the transition to a full resource-based payment system in 2002. The report will examine the effects on payment for physicians' services, interactions with other payment components, and the appropriateness of compensation for physicians. The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission will report to Congress on the impact of refinements to physician payments post transition to a full resource-based payment system in 2002, focusing on the effects on payment for physicians' services, access to care for Medicare beneficiaries, and physician participation in the Medicare program.
